title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Act is amended to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. This information can be used by federal and state agencies administering benefits programs, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use or disclosure. The Commissioner of Social Security can establish safeguards to protect information on deceased individuals when sharing it with federal or state agencies administering benefits programs. This includes cooperating with agencies like the Do Not Pay working system and their Inspector General, ensuring reimbursement for associated costs, and not conflicting with the Commissioner's duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies like the Do Not Pay working system for fraud prevention, as long as safeguards are in place to protect the data. The Commissioner of Social Security can share death information with federal agencies for various purposes such as payment verification, tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. Additionally, similar arrangements can be made with States to provide information on deceased individuals. The Commissioner of Social Security can share death information with federal agencies and States for various purposes, including crime prevention and benefit pension plan administration. The information is subject to safeguards to protect it from unauthorized use. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with federal and state agencies for statistical and research purposes, subject to safeguards. Amendments to the Social Security Act will be repealed five years after enactment. The amendments made to the Social Security Act will be repealed five years after enactment, restoring the original provisions. The Internal Revenue Code is also amended to replace references to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security for sharing deceased individuals' information. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, including State agencies, focusing on accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, and cost. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review the accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability of death data for Federal agencies. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years, including a recommendation on extending agency access to death data distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress with a recommendation on extending agency access to death data distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on accessing death databases for improved data matching within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing electronic records of individual deaths to the Federal Government within 1 year of the enactment of this section. Recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance may be included in the plan. The plan will recommend changes or financial assistance for States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations to provide electronic records of individual deaths to the Federal Government. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Tribal organizations must submit a plan to Congress to enhance data matching with the Federal Government regarding the death of individuals receiving federally funded benefits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide annual reports on the implementation of this plan for five years. Definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are based on the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including identifying errors in records and verifying the status of extremely elderly individuals. The plan required by the Act includes improved policies and procedures for identifying and correcting erroneous records in the Social Security Administration, implementing statistical analysis of death data, and making recommendations for legislation. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement this plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
